Educational Television Research
Series _*
October 3, 1957
TELEVISION AS A MEANS OF MEETING COLLEGE STAFF SHORTAGES AND UPGRADING
GUIDANCE AND COUNSELING SERVICES IN THE SCHOOLS. Walter M. Lifton,
Assoc. Prof., College of Education, Uhiv. of Illinois, mimeo, 10 pages.
"In the face of the growing tide of requests for counselors, counselor
training institutions find themselves unable to either train an adequate
number of new counselors or to travel about the country to assist schools
in their efforts to develop or improve guidance services in their programs."
A proposal by Professor Lifton goes into considerable detail on one sug¬
gested method of meeting these problems.
The anticipated outcomes of the study include*
1. More effective use of teaching personnel to provide guidance
services, especially in schools where no formal programs pre¬
sently exist.
2. A better understanding on the part of students as to their own
responsibilities in our society, and the way they can best
select a career which provides satisfaction.
3. An increased understanding of the changing nature of the world
^ of work by the public, with particular reference to parents.
Associated with this should be a better knowledge of existing
facilities for use in the selection of schools or work,
ij. A better perception of the differences which exist in vocational
planning for rural vs. urban populations.
The project plan and timetable is carefully laid out and no attempt is
really made to condense all the material in this report, because of the
thoroughness and detail into which the proposal discusses each phase of
the project* FACTSHEET readers interested in administrative procedures
of a project of this scope will find it useful to study the full report.
Managers will also appreciate the opportunity to study the details in this
proposed budget of sixty telecasts, since few production costs are ever
made available for comparative cost studies. For this three year project,
the budget has been reduced in this brief report to the following seven
basic items* TV Staff Salaries—$1*2,350.00, Production Costs—$21*,000.00,
Kinescope Recordings—$30,000.00, Monitors for Schools—112,000.00, Guid¬
ance Staff—$29,500.00, Research Staff—131,800.00, General Budget—
$32,1400.00. Total* 1202,050.00
The study itself will be of particular interest to Counselor Trainers.
TV Producer, and TV Managers.
Raymond D. Cheydleur
October 3, 1957
